title: Ethics patches in a box
text:
Generalizability
You can generalize this activity to any internet service where user information is collected for prediction purposes. While this exercise can work in almost any such setting (such as Netflix recommendations), we think it will work best when there is a clear opportunity for comparing and contrasting along some demographic variable, as was the case with StitchFix‚Äôs ‚ÄúStyle Profile‚Äù quiz split along (binary) gender.

title: Ethics patches in a box
text:
Student preparation required
Students should have a basic understanding of statistical modeling: \(y = f(\vec{x}) + \epsilon\) and \(\widehat{y} = \widehat{f}(\vec{x})\) where we have:

Outcome variables, both observed \(y\) and fitted/predicted \(\widehat{y}\)
A ‚Äútrue‚Äù unknown model \(f()\) (i.e.¬†‚Äúsignal‚Äù) and a fitted/approximated model \(\widehat{f}()\)
Explanatory/predictor variables \(\vec{x}\)
An error term \(\epsilon\) (i.e.¬†noise)

Optionally, students who have some familiarity with the difference between ‚Äúmodeling for prediction‚Äù and ‚Äúmodeling for explanation‚Äù will be well placed to absorb the lessons of this patch. For a broad discussion on this differencel, in particular to what ends each modeling paradigm is used for, instructors and upper-level students can read (Breiman et al. 2001).

title: Ethics patches in a box
text:
Instructions for students
In this exercise, you‚Äôll learn that machine learning in practice isn‚Äôt as objective as many may think. Because machine learning algorithms are designed by humans for humans, they consequently incorporate many human biases and beliefs.
The context for this exercise will be one many of you can relate to: shopping for clothes. In particular, we‚Äôll focus on StitchFix, an online clothing subscription service that uses machine learning to predict which clothes will suit your style and hence are likely to buy. They then send you a ‚Äúfix‚Äù of clothes to try at home and you keep only the ones you want.
Today‚Äôs exercise will proceed as follows:

You‚Äôll form groups of ideally two students.
We‚Äôll watch the following 4 minute clip from ABC‚Äôs Good Morning America to familiarize ourselves with StitchFix‚Äôs business model.


In groups you‚Äôll go to StitchFix and complete the ‚ÄúStyle Profile‚Äù quiz that collects information about your clothing preferences as follows:

One of you will sign up for StitchFix.
Together you‚Äôll both complete the quiz for one of the (binary) choices of gender: men or women.
The other group member will then sign up for StitchFix.
Together you‚Äôll both complete the quiz for the other choice of gender. Make note of any differences you find interesting.

We‚Äôll have a class discussion relating this experience to the topics we‚Äôve been learning in class and the notion of algorithmic bias.

title: Ethics patches in a box
text:
Activity description
This activity can be self-contained in a single 50 minute lecture as follows:

(5 minutes): Give students above instructions.
(5 minutes): Watch clip from Good Morning America.
(20 minutes): Have the student groups complete both the men‚Äôs and women‚Äôs ‚ÄúStyle Profile‚Äù quiz.
(10 minutes): Class discussion. Potential prompts include:

‚ÄúWhat sociological biases and beliefs are embedded in the quizzes?‚Äù There are too many to enumerate and thus we recommend the instructor complete both quizzes beforehand to get a sense for themselves.
‚ÄúWhat predictor variables are being collected in the quizzes both directly as well as indirectly?‚Äù Examples of the latter include date/time (hence season), browser/operating system (these are weakly tied with technological sophistication and income), and shipping address (hence climate).
‚ÄúWhat are the principal components to consider when buying clothes?‚Äù In our opinion, the user‚Äôs style (patterns, cuts, colors), fit (lengths, proportions), and budget.
‚ÄúWhat modeling method \(\widehat{f}()\) do you think is being used by StitchFix?‚Äù While \(\widehat{f}()\) is proprietary to StitchFix and thus unknown, given the initial prompt for the user to select ‚Äúmen‚Äù or ‚Äúwomen‚Äù, at the very highest level \(\widehat{f}()\) is a decision tree a split on gender encoded as a binary variable.
‚ÄúWhat crucial predictor variable \(\vec{x}\) can StitchFix only collect after they‚Äôve sent you your first fix?‚Äù Examples include which clothes you keep, which clothes you return, and the ratings/feedback you give.
‚ÄúWhat is being predicted by these models and what is being reinforced?‚Äù A much more rhetorical question.

(5 minutes): Give a brief lecture on algorithmic bias.
(5 minutes): Give students instructions on the reflection piece they need to submit.

title: Ethics patches in a box
text:
Deliverables
A reflection piece written by students summarizing their experiences and thoughts, ideally addressing the questions and goals in the previous section.
